title.narrative: Citizen Security Program
N/A
N/A
Programa de Seguridad Ciudadana

description.narrative: Contribuir a la reducción de los índices de crimen y violecia y de los niveles de inseguridad de los ciudadanos.
To assist in the reduction and prevention of crime and violence rates and the levels of insecurity of the citizens.

activity-description.narrative: CSP partnered with YMCA to implement its “Shoot to Live” project in the Beetham Gardens community. The purpose being to point young persons aged between 15-18 years old in a direction away from crime. This was accomplished by teaching practical vocational skills of photography and videography while providing mentorship and life skills training.

In collaboration with a local NGO, Families in Action, the Citizen Security Programme sponsored a conflict and anger management programme for residents of Embacadere, San Fernando. The title of the programme was “Together We Achieve Growth” and it involved working with both parents and children over a duration of 13 weeks to impart them with improved communication skills, conflict management skills, stress management and other critical life skills such as peer refusal and problem solving.

In the CSP community of Enterprise, a PHI training programme was held for residents. The PHI instrument stands for Percussive Harmonic Instrument and it is the first electronic version of the steelpan, Trinidad and Tobago’s national instrument, to be made. This programme was implemented in collaboration with the University of the West Indies and the T&TEC Tropical Angel Harps for interested residents in the community.

In the La Romain CSP community, a computer resource centre was established for the residents living there. This centre specifically targeted those without computer access in their homes, affording them the opportunity to fully utilize the centre for academic, learning and other recreational uses.

In the community of Glen Road/Darrell Spring, the Citizen Security Programme partnered with the Arrow Foundation for literacy programmes designed to improve the reading and spelling of participating children.

In the community of Gonzales, the Citizen Security Programme helped host an event titled “Capacity Building- Strengthening Organizational Capacity” in collaboration with a local non-profit organization called The Rose Foundation. This programme specifically seeks to transform weak grassroots community based organizations into sustainable, legitimate entities.

Sogren Trace is located in West Laventille, Trinidad and overlooks the capital city known as Port-of-Spain. The community of approximately 1,520 persons is made up of low to middle income families. The population of school aged (7 – 12 years) children in Sogren Trace Laventille currently attending school is 173 persons or 11% of residents.

Subsequent to the full abolishment of slavery in the second quarter of the nineteenth century, Trinidad and Tobago declared August 1st as a national holiday in 1985 to commemorate the event and it has since been known as Emancipation Day. Since then, it continues to be a cause for celebration and as such, the Citizen Security Programme partnered with the Mon Repos community to host a well-received Emancipation Show.

The Beetham Gardens CSP community has a population of approximately 3,258 residents with around 39% of them being young persons aged between 7-24 years old. The community has several recreational facilities, including a basketball court and football fields. Here is a scene of a football game organized for members in the community on International Men’s day.

The Bon Accord community has a population of approximately 2,247 residents. One way in which the community has been engaged is through the Bon Accord Murals Project. This initiative consisted of the cleaning, painting and creation of imagery with positive messages along the walls surrounding the Bon Accord Primary School, where it actively involved the children and young persons in the community.

The CSP community of Bethel has a population of about 1,871 residents. It is a traditional village with modest housing scattered with pockets of low income housing. One way which the Citizen Security Programme has engaged the community is through the hosting of a safety fair for the residents in collaboration with national forces under the Ministry of National Security.

The CSP community of Dibe, Belle Vue and Dundonald Hill has a population of approximately 2,323 people. It has been estimated that 35% of their population is comprised of young persons between the ages of 7-24 years old. Depicted here is a Child Abuse Prevention Training Workshop that was held for the community in collaboration with a local NGO, The Rape Crisis Society of Trinidad and Tobago (RCS).

The CSP community of Mt. D’or Road has approximately 2,663 residents living there. Mt. D'or Road has a recreational ground located within its boundaries, as well as a basketball court for use by its residents. Depicted in this photograph is a scene taken from a friendly cricket tournament that was arranged for the community.

The CSP community of Patna/River Estate has a population of approximately 2,340 residents. Young people aged between 7-24 years old represent approximately 39% of the population and it has been reported that around 33% of the population earn less than TTD$500 (USD$78) per month. One way in which the community has been engaged is by the hosting of different events, such as “Healthy Lifestyles Promote Healthy Communities.”

The CSP community of Quash Trace is comprised of approximately 3,000 persons. It has been reported that a large number of its population are below the age of 40 and almost a quarter of its residents fall between the ages of 7 and 24 years old. The picture here shows a scene taken from a family day held for the community.

The CSP community of St. Barb’s has a population of approximately 4,945 residents. It has been reported that around 32% of the population earn less than TTD$500 (USD$78) per month. Depicted here is a health caravan that was organized by CSP for the benefit of the community.

The Cocorite community has approximately 4,058 persons residing there. It has been reported that around 39% of its population earn less than TTD$500 (USD$78) per month. The CSP uses street theatre as a means to communicate pro social messages to residents. Depicted here is a scene from a street theatre event organized for the community.

The Covigne Road CSP community has approximately 3,611 persons living there. It has been reported that approximately 36% of their population is made up of young persons aged between 7-24 years old. With regard to available extracurricular spaces, the youth utilize an area called “The Tank Yard” to play football and there is a basketball court too. Here is a scene from the “Discovering the Streams Youth Camp” that was done in collaboration with the Divine Destiny Worship Centre.

The Enterprise community has a population of approximately 10,871 persons with approximately 39% being between the ages of 7-24 years old. CSP partnered with the Enterprise Community Action Council to host a Walk for Peace and Caravan for the community with the aim of sensitizing them to the seriousness of crime and violence. Residents were also presented with several alternatives to a life of crime while creating an opportunity for them to come together in support of making a change.

The Farm Road community has a population of approximately 900 people and the community is mostly comprised of low income families. It has been reported that a larger percentage of the community is made up of young people aged between 12-29 years old. The picture here is of a child abuse prevention training session held for the community of Farm Road in collaboration with a local NGO, The Rape Crisis Society of Trinidad and Tobago (RCS).

The Gonzales community has a population of approximately 5,650 people. The community has been described as a low-income area with high levels of unemployment. One of the ways the Citizen Security Programme has engaged the community is by assisting in the organizing of health fairs and caravans.

The La Romaine community has approximately 9,072 residents living there. It has been reported that around 45% are young persons aged between 7 – 24 years old. Depicted here is a scene taken from a Christmas Treat that the Citizen Security Programme played a part in organizing for the community.

The Never Dirty community has a total population of approximately 1,342 persons. The Citizen Security Programme has engaged the community by coordinating the CHAMP Programme which seeks to address early sexual initiation among teens by providing life skills training and information to teens, and both coaching and support to their parents to improve their monitoring and communication skills. Residents are trained to deliver the programme.

The North Eastern Settlement CSP community has a population of approximately 9,000 people. The community is mostly comprised of single headed households and households where common-law relationships are the norm. One of the objectives of the Citizen Security Programme is to reduce injuries related to child maltreatment and domestic violence. Depicted here is a session held within the community to address both.

The Pinto Road community has a population of approximately 8,000 people. It has been reported that 41% of the population are between the ages of 7 and 24 years old. The community is mostly comprised of low to middle income families with about 41% earning less than TTD$500 (USD$78) per month. As one of its community engagement activities, CSP partnered with a Community Based Organisation to host a summer vacation camp for children. Some 250 residents benefitted from the camp.

The Sogren Trace CSP community has a population of approximately 1,520 people with about 36% of their residents being young people aged between 10-24 years old. The community has a number of recreational facilities available for use by its residents. Portrayed here is a family and fun day that was held in collaboration with their Community Action Council and one of the two resident pre-schools in Sogren Trace, St. Ann’s Pre-school.

The Young Women’s Christian Association (YWCA) worked together with the Citizen Security Programme to conduct a gender based violence prevention programme for the community based in Covigne Road, Diego Martin. Through community engagement and training, the programme addressed gender based violence, sexual and reproductive health, conflict resolution and other related topics. Depicted here is one of the learning tools used to illustrate and tell the problematic story of gender based violence.

The community of Embacadere has approximately 1,349 persons living there and is mostly made up of low to middle income families. The Citizen Security Programme has engaged the community in a number of ways, including the hosting of sporting events, such as the friendly cricket match depicted here.

The community of Mon Repos has approximately 2,959 residents. One way in which they have been engaged by the Citizen Security Programme is through what is known as the Rapid Impact Project (RIP). These are intended to serve several purposes including capacity building and improving the quality of life. Depicted here is an agricultural training program that was arranged for the community.

The community of Samaroo Village/Mootoo Lands has a population of approximately 1,458 people. It has been reported that approximately 56% of the population are persons aged less than 29 years old with 40% being between the ages of 7-24 years old. One way the community has been engaged by the Citizens Security Programme is through an event hosted that was titled “An Evening of Dance, Music and Fashion.” This event was organized by the residents of the community.
The picture here was taken at a Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) training workshop that the Citizen Security Programme organized for its partner Non-Governmental Organizations.

The “Not Meee! Crime Game” was a board game created as a crime prevention teaching tool. The game was created in collaboration with the Proactive Crime Team and these youngsters from the CSP community of Embacadere were one of the first that got to play it.

The “Pinto Road Resource Centre” project is one that was done in collaboration with the Pinto Road Village Council. It specifically targeted those in the community without computer access, allowing them the opportunity to take full advantage of the centre.

The “Shoot to Live” project supported by the Citzen Security Programme in partnership with the YMCA of Trinidad and Tobago is one that has been most succesful. This has led to the intiative being undertaken in more than one community. In 2012, a short film about the project was actually created and screened at the Trinidad and Tobago Film Festival. This picture shows some of the beautiful work of participants from Beetham Gardens on display at a local gallery.

The “Youth Transformation through Music” project was done in collaboration with the Community Transformation Foundation. When it comes to music, Trinidad and Tobago is the land of calypso, soca and many other forms of musical genres that have been created by its people. As the title of the project suggests, the project targeted the youth in the CSP community of St. Barb’s and actively taught them both the practical and theoretical elements of music literacy.
Violence prevention training was held for the CSP communities in Tobago in the vicinity of Bon Accord. The training was conducted in the form of a workshop addressing the theme of mediation.

Violence prevention training was jointly held for the CSP communities of Never Dirty, Mon Repos and Patna/River Estate. The training was conducted in the form of a workshop addressing the theme of domestic violence.

Violence prevention training was jointly held for the CSP communities of Samaroo Village/Mootoo Lands and Pinto Road. The training was conducted in the form of a workshop addressing the theme of domestic violence.

Vocational training is one of the ways in which the Citizen Security Programme has partnered with the community of Enterprise, Chaguanas. The depicted activity is that of a sponsored beauty culture course meant to train and impart a variety of skills that may in turn motivate its participants to seek gainful employment in such establishments or encourage the creation of micro-entrepreneurial businesses.

“Put a Glove on Crime” was a boxing tournament organized by the Citizen Security Programme in collaboration with the World Class Boxing Gym for the Covigne Road community. The activity engaged several persons in the community and was meant as a way to steer residents away from a life of crime and at the same time allowed them to partake in friendly competition.
